2 Settings

The settings section includes a series of variables to configure our project. You could find two differente types of variables; the default ones which should be modified v√≠a theming and the immutable ones which are internally used by the framework and shouldn't be modified.

Variables

var default value desc
$egeo-namespace
 !defaultinternal egeo-
A prefix included in all classes created by the UI Kit. This variable is used internally so change it could cause unexpected results.
$egeo-nobem-namespace
 !defaultinternal egeo-nobem-
A prefix included in all classes created by the UI Kit to be used in projects which are not using BEM like naming methodology. This variable is used internally so change it could cause unexpected results.
$egeo-fontface-src
 !default 'assets/fonts'
A base url from which the @font-face directive will seek the font folders.
$egeo-silent-classes
 !default false
Active/deactivate the use of silent classes (view en explanation about silent classes below).

Why a UI Kit namespace?

The use of a namespace that prefix all classes exposed ensures that the classes of the framework will have no collisions with the classes defined in the project the framework will be imported on.

Why a non-BEM namespace?

When you are building a project using BEM Methodology, created by Yandex, you are building a CSS with flat specificity due to almost all selectors used are delimited to one class, that is equal to 10 points of specificity. That means that if you load the files of the framework in the right order, the classes always be respond as expected, overwritten the styles necessary, for example, when you are using utils.

However, if you are not working with BEM or you are using external libraries not built with BEM like Bootstrap, AngularUI or Foundation, then you have to overwritte some styles using !important flag due to you have no way to know what specifity could have a selector. Even knowing it, you would have to create a selector specifically written for each selector you want to overwrite. A mess.

For that, some classes and placeholders in the framework uses the non-BEM namespace to ensure that the !important flag is used and they can overwrite any class in the project.

Silent Classes

It is possible that, in any cases, you want to use some of the Egeo features but you don't want to import all the classes generated in your final CSS due to obvious performance reasons. If not used, shouldn't appear.

All CSS classes in the Egeo UI Kit even in the Base Framework, are generated throughout mixins. This means that we can enable/disable the generation of the CSS class and import only the mixins to our code or import only the CSS classes we really need to use. This technique is called Silent Classes.

By default, Egeo considers that you want to generate all CSS classes you import so the default value of $egeo-silent-classes is false. If you set it as true, by default, the system will only provide you the mixins and you have to set manually, class by class, if you want to generate the CSS class or not.

To do it, all Egeo components include a variable called like the component that is a boolean. For example, the Button component that has the mixin egeo-c-button includes a variable called $egeo-c-button to indicate if Egeo should generate the CSS class or not. By default, this variable will have the value of $egeo-silent-classes.

2.1 settings.colors

In this file are defined the variables related to the use of colors. By default, the colors included in the main Sass map $colors are the ones defined by the Design Team in the visual specification.

Variables

var default desc
$colors
 !default
The default Sass map of colors. By default, the map includes the whole colors of the visual specification.

Sass Map $colors

c1: #37b5e4
a1: #37b5e4

a2_light: #ccd9de

2.2 settings.typography

In this file are defined the variables related to the use of typography.

Variables

font-variant: default desc
$egeo-font-families
 !default
The default Sass map of font families declared in the visual specifications.
$egeo-font-weights
 !default
The default Sass map of font weights declared in the visual specifications.
$egeo-font-sizes
 !default
The default Sass map of font sizes declared in the visual specifications.
$egeo-line-heights
 !default
The default Sass map of line heights declared in the visual specifications.

Sass map $egeo-font-families

The $egeo-font-families map includes, althought the font families used, a series of alias to hide the font family behind the purpose of that font and protect our app of the changes in the typographies at future. For example, we can use egeo-get-font(heading) instead of egeo-get-font(brandon-grotesque). The final result will be the same but, if in the future the design team decides that the font for the heading will be Monotype, our code will be safe due to when the framework update the font reference of the heading value, we will only need to recompile the Sass code to obtain the new value in all places we are using it.

Result Value Key
Brandon Grotesque Brandon Grotesque brandon-grotesque
Open Sans Open Sans open-sans
Droid Sans DroidSansMonoRegular droid-sans
ico_stratio stratio-iconfont
Heading Brandon Grotesque heading
Body Open Sans body
Code DroidSansMonoRegular code
icon stratio-iconfont

Sass map $egeo-font-sizes

The $egeo-font-sizes map is really a merge of three different maps: $egeo-head-font-sizes, $egeo-icon-font-sizes and $egeo-body-font-sizes as it is described in the Visual Guidelines.

Result Value Key
Heading in Brandon Grotesque 2.75rem head_giant
Heading in Brandon Grotesque 2.12rem head_xxxlarge
Heading in Brandon Grotesque 1.88rem head_xxlarge
Heading in Brandon Grotesque 1.75rem head_xlarge
Heading in Brandon Grotesque 1.5rem head_large
Heading in Brandon Grotesque 1.38rem head_medium
Heading in Brandon Grotesque 1.13rem head_small
Heading in Brandon Grotesque 1rem head_xsmall
Heading in Brandon Grotesque .94rem head_xxsmall
Heading in Brandon Grotesque .82rem head_xxxsmall
Heading in Brandon Grotesque .75rem head_mini
1.88rem icon_xxlarge
1.63rem icon_xlarge
1.38rem icon_large
1.2rem icon_medium
1.1rem icon_small
.94rem icon_xsmall
.82rem icon_xxsmall
.7rem icon_xxxsmall
Body in Open Sans 1.38rem body_xxxlarge
Body in Open Sans 1.19rem body_xxlarge
Body in Open Sans 1.1rem body_xlarge
Body in Open Sans 1rem body_large
Body in Open Sans .94rem body_medium
Body in Open Sans .84rem body_small
Body in Open Sans .82rem body_xsmall
Body in Open Sans .75rem body_xxsmall
Body in Open Sans .69rem body_xxxsmall

Sass map $egeo-font-weights

Result Value Key
Open Sans 900 bolder
Open Sans 700 bold
Open Sans 500 semibold
Open Sans 400 normal
Open Sans 200 light

Sass map $egeo-line-heights

double

2.3 settings.icons

This file only include an import of the Stratio Icon Font. You can see the detail of the whole icons imported in the visual reference.

To use any icon, you only need to create a tag with the class of the icon. All classes are defined in the visual reference.

Markup

<i class="icon-datetime"></i>

Compatibility

The Stratio Icon Font is provided in EOT, SVG, TTF and WOFF formats so it is compatible with all modern browsers and the most of the older ones. You can see a compatibility table of this formats in the fonts section.

2.4 settings.fonts

This file only include an import of the Fonts specified in the visual reference. You can see below the families and formats imported as well as a reference compatibility table.

Fonts

Font Families Formats available
Brandon Grotesque
Light, Regular, Bold, Black
 EOT, SVG, TTF, WOFF
Open Sans
Light, LightItalic, Regular, Italic, Semibold, SemiboldItalic, Bold, BoldItalic, ExtraBold, ExtraBoldItalic
 EOT, SVG, TTF, WOFF

Compatibility

Font format IE Chrome Firefox Safari Opera Edge
TTF/OTF 9.0+* 4.0+ 3.5+ 3.1+ 10.0+ 12+
WOFF 9.0+ 5.0+ 3.6+ 5.1+ 11.1+ 12+
WOFF2 not supported 36.0+ 35.0* not supported 26.0+ 12+
SVG not supported 4.0+ not supported 3.2+ 9.0+ 12+
EOT 6.0+ not supported not supported not supported not supported 12+
  • IE: The font format only works when set to be "installable".
  • Firefox: Disabled by default, but can be enabled (need to set a flag to "true" to use WOFF2).

Compatible in IE8+, Edge 12+, Firefox 3.5+, Chrome 4+, Safari 3.1+, Opera 9+

Dependencies

  • tools.log: The fonts uses the logger tool to show debug info.

2.5 settings.layers

In this file are defined the variables related to the use of different layers in the app. When you work in any web project, often it is needed to fight with multiple z-index declarations across different CSS files or in one only big CSS with thousands lines of code. This library, working with tools.layers provides a set of tools to abstract all this complexity referencing the layer deeps with descriptive names, helping developers to set the CSS classes in the appropiate layer without the use of magic numbers.

Variables

var default desc
$egeo-layers
 !default
The default Sass map of layers. This map is only a set of pairs key/value that represents name/number of deep.

Sass Map $layers

key value
back -10
sub-2 -2
sub-1 -1
base 0
top-1 1
top-2 2
top-3 3
ontop 10
Created using kss-node and kss-node-template.
